urn:contentItem:5KYV-M4P1-F0J6-J251-00000-00Wet weather closes firewood areas2016-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisWet weather closes firewood areasSophie Boyd

WIMMERA's wet weather has caused the early closure of several fire collection areas in the region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's District Manager Russell Manning said some areas would close due to safety concerns.

"Our staff have been vigilant in their assessment of conditions and have advised that many of areas are either inaccessible due to recent heavy rain or track conditions are such that providing access would only damage tracks," he said.

He said the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning would not open the following fire collection areas:

Mr Manning said all other areas are safe for collectors.

"We believe that there are adequate supplies of firewood in these areas, of varying sizes and quality," he said.

"Unless otherwise advised, all other designated Firewood Collection Areas will remain open until 30 November 2016, offering good access if collectors stay on marked tracks."

Mr Manning asked residents to collect firewood by hand and said to be prepared to carry the wood some distance to their vehicle.

He said it was illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence or to take more than the allowed amount.

Mr Manning said any information the community may have about the illegal removal of firewood for sale can be reported to DELWP on 136 186 and quote Operation Axe.

To find your nearest firewood collection area or for more information and updates, visit www.delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood , your nearest DELWP office or call the Customer Service Centre on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5NND-9391-F0J6-J1KR-00000-00Pilot handing back control2017-05-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Pilot handing back controlNatalie Croxon

RESIDENTS of West Bendigo have worked with firefighting experts to find alternatives to planned burns to cut the risk of bushfires in the area.

Jonathan Andrea, from Forest Fire Management Victoria, said residents raised the possibility of alternatives to burning when consulted on plans for an area near Inglis Street, off Marong Road.

Through phone calls, meetings and information sessions over the past year, Mr Andrea said, residents and FFM Victoria agreed to undertake a mix of fuel reduction methods, to be completed in two stages.

The first stage has involved mulching, which has already begun and will take about another week to complete.

"We are mulching areas of thick vegetation that has regrown at the site after the Black Saturday fires passed through in 2009," Mr Andrea said.

Experts will then reassess the site and targeted burns may take place in areas not conducive to mulching.

"Planned burns will remain an important technique in bushfire preparedness but equally as important â€” in consultation with communities â€” is to consider other options of reducing risk such as mulching, slashing and grooming works," Mr Andrea said.

"These methods are an effective fuel management option where the terrain and vegetation are suitable."

He said the collaboration was undertaken as part of the agency's new 'Safer Together' approach to managing bushfire risk.

"Being safer together means involving local communities in decision making about bushfire management all year round, understanding what people care most about and working with them to determine local solutions, as is the case here at Inglis Street," Mr Andrea said.

"We're here to listen to everyone's perspective, including community members who have concerns about planned burns."

Under the 'Safer Together' approach, the government says there will be greater CFA involvement in planned burns on public land, integrated planning involving all agencies and communities, and collaboration between land and fire agencies to deliver fuel management programs.

urn:contentItem:5RFY-6TF1-F0J6-J38K-00000-00Car set alight in heat as firefighters on standby2018-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisCar set alight in heat as firefighters on standbyBlair Thomson

POLICE have slammed the actions of an arsonist who has torched a car in hot weather.

The vehicle was set on fire on the side of the Murray Valley Highway at Browns Plains, west of Wodonga, about 11pm on Friday.

The 2003 model Mitsubishi Magna was gutted and flames spread to nearby grass.

Detective Senior Constable Ian Deverell said the arson was stupid and dangerous.

"This sort of thing can quickly cause a lot of damage to property and can endanger people's lives," he said.

"It's a senseless crime and it's got me bewildered why people do this sort of thing.

"It's that time of year where the grass is drying out.

"Anyone who sees any suspicious activity or cars, or anything connected to arson and fire, can contact Crime Stoppers."

The vehicle had not been reported stolen.

The car had been smashed before the fire, with extensive damage to the roof.

It had broken down and been abandoned before the incident.

"We're appealing for any members of the public who may have seen someone in the area or seen a car nearby to contact Wodonga police," he said.

"The car had been sitting there for a while."

Firefighters attended and extinguished the flames.

The incident came at the end of a 39-degree day.

Police and firefighters ran incident control centres at the weekend amid concerns about the risk of fire.

Wodonga incident controller Graham Healy said fire crews were on standby with maximum temperatures of close to 40 degrees forecast all week.

"We've been operating all weekend under a one-hour standby," he said.

"The teams have all been assembled.

"The forest fire danger rating is very high, bordering on severe."

Conditions today and tomorrow are also concerning, Mr Healy said, with high temperatures forecast.

"We want people to be vigilant," he said.

"Everyone in the community should report what they see.

"We're probably just getting into summer conditions now and there is a lot of fuel out there."

Mr Healy said risky conditions could continue until the end of next month.

"Our fire danger won't come down again until we get some decent rain."

urn:contentItem:5MFP-R4W1-JD34-V2NR-00000-00Be ready for bushfire2016-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisINSIDE FRONTPg. 2Be ready for bushfire

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning is warning those heading into the bush over the summer months keep in mind the potential for bushfires, particularly in central Victorian forests and parks.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting assistant chief fire officer Carsten Nannestad said the idea it was safe to remain in a forested area until flames were visible was a myth.

"People imagine they will see flames before being confronted by a bushfire, but often smoke will be the first warning," he said.

"Remember to take plenty of food, water, and extra fuel just in case you have to travel further to leave your camp."

Mr Nannestad said monitoring weather conditions was crucial in heading off disaster in the bush.

"Before heading into the bush check the weather forecast and prepare for the conditions," he said.

"Remember the weather can change rapidly and having the right gear could help you arrive home safely."

While most smartphones have their own global positioning systems, Mr Nannestad said it was a mistake to rely on these in an emergency.

"Most smartphones have a GPS, but to avoid relying on cellular networks in remote environments take a separate GPS," he said.

"The benefit of a GPS unit is that it communicates directly with GPS satellites, bypassing cellular networks.

"If you need to get out quickly and you don't know the area well, a GPS could help you out."

If a fire does occur, Mr Nannestad said sturdy footwear and a set of woollen clothing and a woollen blanket would provide a good layer of insulation and help protect against radiant heat.

Safety tips when visiting parks and forests during summer, include:

For more visit www.delwp.vic.gov.au or   www.emergency.vic.gov.au and download the VicEmergency app.

urn:contentItem:5PJS-7641-F0JP-W0TK-00000-00Out-of-control burn-off fears2017-09-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Out-of-control burn-off fearsBarry Kennedy

FIREFIGHTERS got a taste of what to expect across the Macedon Ranges this summer after a private burn-off got out of control in Tylden.

CFA crews from Tylden, Kyneton, Trentham, Woodend and Carlsruhe joined -forces to put out the 8.1ha fire which started after a landowner burned off the -remains of a former blue gum plantation.

Tylden CFA captain Liam Miles said the September 18 fire was hard to access and high winds added to the difficulties for firefighters.

"We haven't had to attend a burn-off like this for a number of years," he said. "The former plantation had been cut down. It seemed the property owner's idea was to dispose of the -remnants with a fire.

"Burn-offs have to be -registered and weather -conditions monitored in the lead-up and on the day of the planned burn." The blaze comes after the region was declared as -having "significant fire -potential" in the Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook, released by the -Bureau of Meteorology in consultation with fire and land managers.

Victorian Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said preparations were already under way for the fire season.

"The early forecast shows there is underlying dryness in some areas of the state, particularly across central parts of Victoria and across the east," he said.

Works to prepare for the season have included Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA bringing forward planned burns, including near Gisborne last week.

Mr Lapsley urged residents to start their fire prevention works and "get ready and prepare your properties, yourself and your family".

CFA North Western -community safety manager David Allen said preparations were stepping up across Sunbury and the -Macedon Ranges.

The Hesket-Kerrie and Benloch communities are taking part in the State Government-supported Safer -Together program, where they will work on strategies with the DELWP, Parks Victoria, CFA and Macedon Ranges Council."It's all about agencies working together with communities to identify the risks and challenges of living in these areas," Mr Allen said.

urn:contentItem:51MT-Y3X1-JD3N-50BB-00000-00Air assault brings fire in Israel under control2010-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 9Air assault brings fire in Israel under controlABRAHAM RABINOVICH

JERUSALEM: A forest fire that burned out of control for more than three days and threatened Haifa, Israel's third-largest city, was brought under control yesterday after a massive air assault from tanker aircraft from nine countries.

Officials said on Sunday night the forests were still smouldering and that strong winds might whip up new fires. But rainfall that began yesterday morning -- the first rain since last winter -- lent assurance that the ordeal was over.

Forty-two people were killed in the fire, almost all of them trainee prison warders. They were on their way to evacuate a prison in the Carmel Mountain forest that was threatened by fire when flames overtook their bus.

About 4000ha of forest, including five million trees, were consumed. Reported among the dead last night was Haifa's police chief, Ahuva Tomer, who suffered burns to more than 80 per cent of her body. The fire forced the evacuation of thousands of Haifa residents.

Officials attributed the swift suppression of the blaze to the aerial attack. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was credited for having taken the initiative to request assistance from foreign countries.

``It was a game-changing decision,'' wrote Nahum Barnea, the Yediot Aharonot columnist often critical of Mr Netanyahu as a posturing and indecisive leader. Mr Netanyahu made his decision after fire officers said they could not control the fire being spread by powerful winds across tinder-dry forests.

Mr Netanyahu said he came upon the idea earlier this year during a lunch in Greece with his counterpart, Prime Minister George Papandreou. ``There was a forest fire across the bay and we saw planes dumping water on it,'' said Mr Netanyahu. ``He said that's the way they put out large fires, not from the ground.''

urn:contentItem:5NJD-P8R1-F0J6-J178-00000-00traditional burns2017-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5traditional burnsNatalie Croxon

TRADITIONAL Aboriginal burning practices are again being used to manage the natural environment, in what is a first for Victoria.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Bendigo-based staff and the Dja Dja Wurrung Aboriginal Clans Corporation have partnered to reintroduce traditional burns to the landscape, with the first two undertaken earlier this week in Maryborough and Whipstick.

Parks Victoria's Dja Dja Wurrung ranger team leader and chair of the corporation, Trent Nelson, said the practice was putting "Dja Dja Wurrung people back in the landscape".

Mr Nelson said the traditional burns would not take away from other practices such as planned burns, but would add Aboriginal knowledge and skills to the mix.

As well as act in fuel management, he said the reintroduction of traditional burns would help heal the natural environment.

FFM assistant chief fire officer Scott Falconer said traditional burns would have a legitimate place in fuel management going forward.

"This is a really important step in (reintroducing) something that has been absent, in a structured way, for 150, 200 years," Mr Falconer said.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning's Dja Dja Wurrung district planner Mick Bourke said education was an important aspect of the project.

With much traditional knowledge lost, those involved in the project are talking to elders, reading settlers' accounts and old journals, and monitoring their own burn activities.

As a result, Mr Bourke said, this knowledge would be able to be passed down to younger generations.

He said educating the community was also essential, and fire was not something to be feared, but a useful tool when harnessed in the right way.

Traditional burns differ from planned burns in that they are cooler, slower burns, with fires lit in patches and allowed to take their natural paths.

It is hoped the combination of traditional and modern land management methods will become common practice across Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5TG1-JC91-F0J6-J3W3-00000-00News Focus | Grains Innovation Park's world leading research | Photos2018-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4News Focus | Grains Innovation Park's world leading research | Photos

FOR 50 years, scientists and researchers at Horsham's Grains Innovation Park have worked tirelessly to future-proof our country's agriculture industry.

A group of passionate Wimmera farmers first planted the seed to develop the research site in 1967. The facility - then named the Victorian Wheat Research Institute - was opened the following year on November 29, 1968.

Now in 2018, the park is home to the Australian Grains Genebank, the Victorian Fisheries Authority, Regional Development Victoria, the Department of Land, Water and Planning's Forest Fire Management Victoria and Horsham Incident Control Centre, and a number of private tenants.

There are more than 150 staff members employed at the park, including about 100 Agriculture Victoria research, extension, biosecurity and animal health staff working at regional, national and international levels.

Park research director and centre leader Traci Griffin said employees were conducting critical research to future-proof the world's food supply.

"A lot of the work they are focusing on at the moment is around seasonal conditions," she said.

"The Australian Grains Genebank is the only facility in Australia that manages grains, so all the representations of seeds that we need from overseas and at home are stored at the bank.

"It's a very important site that's a national centre, not a just a regional centre. They are dealing with pretty critical stuff and looking ahead a lot longer than just our lifetimes.

"They're trying to ensure that the types of grains our framers use are adapting to climate changes and are keeping up with market conditions."

Related: Editorial | Future-proofing our agriculture industry

She said, although there were a number of trials onsite, trial paddocks were located across the country.

"From here we have trials in NSW, SA and WA, and the idea is that we're constantly testing different soil types," she said.

"The majority of our work is done either on a farmers' paddocks, or with businesses or grower groups. It's great if it works in a lab but it's useless if it can't be used in a paddock."

Ms Griffin said it was important to recognise the park's achievements.

"Not only do we have some amazing science facilities, but we have it in a regional context and that doesn't happen all the time," she said.

"The site is a major employer for the region; we have more than 30 different nationalities represented. We also get tours every week so it's a drawcard to bring people to the Wimmera."

The park will celebrate its 50 year anniversary on Thursday, 18 October. Community members are invited to see firsthand the world-class research happening in the Wimmera.

Tours of the park's various facilities will be held throughout the day from 11am. There will also be displays and demonstrations.

urn:contentItem:3SPD-SVG0-0048-T2W9-00000-00<published>1998-05-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:36:44Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>CAM: SOUTHERN US PLAGUED BY FOREST-FIRE HAZE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">AUSTIN, Texas, May 14 AFP - Haze sweeping into the southern United States from fires in Mexico and Central America forced scores of people indoors today as officials expanded a health alert and urged the White House to send firefighters south of the border.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Texas hospitals reported an increase in the number of visits for respiratory complaints, and officials in bordering Louisiana said they had increased monitoring efforts as they pondered whether to issue their own alert.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The haze has drifted as far north as Missouri and as far east as Florida, weather officials said.</p><p>In Washington, several Texas congressmen wrote a letter to President Clinton urging him to take action against the "growing national emergency".</p><p>Texas Governor George Bush said he is ready to help now and described the diplomatic red tape required for sending aid "a little frustrating".</p><p> White House spokesman Eric Rubin said the US embassy in Mexico was in contact with the Mexican government, adding: "If there's any way we can help, we will."</p><p> triggered by farmers who traditionally burn their fields this time of year. Several months of drought caused by El Nino have intensified the blazes, weather experts say.</p><p> Soot from the fires, described as the worst in half a century, was first visible in Texas last week. But officials did not declare a public health alert until Tuesday, when the smoke reappeared after a brief respite.</p><p> Today, the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission (TNRCC) extended the alert for the affected coastal areas until Monday and declared a "watch" for all but a few areas in west Texas.</p><p> In the "alert" area, affecting millions along the coast from the tip of south Texas to the Louisiana border, all residents  <br/> particularly the young, elderly and anyone with respiratory or heart ailments  were urged to avoid physical exertion and<br/> encouraged to stay indoors, preferably in an air-conditioned environment.</p><p> In the newly designated "watch" area, there were no specific instructions but officials said the sick and elderly would likely be affected.</p><p> "It's evident that the haze at least has the potential to affect many more people than are in the alert area," said TNRCC spokesman Patrick Crimmons, explaining why the agency declared a broad "watch" area. "The haze is kind of everywhere."</p><p> Of particular concern is the tiny, or "fine", particulate matter, which can get trapped deep in the lungs. In Houston and Galveston, located in the "alert" zone, hospitals reported an increase in the number of patients seeking care for respiratory ailments, according to the Houston Chronicle.</p><p> Environmentalists were quick to blast the government for bungling the effort to inform residents about the dangers of the smoke. Many wondered why no alert was called last week.</p><p> Neil Carman, clean-air program director for the TexasSierra Club, an environmental group, called on state officials to invest in more sophisticated technology to detect the smoke.</p><p> "The bad air we breathe today shows up in costly and debilitating health impacts later in life," he said.</p><p>AFP jnb</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SPD-SVG0-0048-T2W9-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="523"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5WF5-M0S1-DY19-C2MH-00000-00Queensland braces for another 'long and busy' bushfire season2019-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisQueensland braces for another 'long and busy' bushfire seasonLydia Lynch

The warning comes as the opposition accuses the Queensland government of sitting on a report into last year's devastating bushfires.

Record heat and below-average rainfall have left great swathes of Queensland exposed to increased risk of bushfires, hot on the heels of the worst bushfire season in the state's history.

The Northern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook, released on Thursday, predicts "above normal fire potential" for the 2019 season.

Last year, the state hit "catastrophic" bushfire levels for the first time as more than a million hectares of land burnt, thousands were evacuated from their homes and a volunteer firefighter was killed.

In its 2019 report, the research centre warned new vegetation in some parts of the state could could fuel bushfires.

"Record warmth and significant rainfall deficiencies have shaped the fire outlook potential across most of northern Australia this season," it said.

"Since 1990, there has been a trend for Queensland fire seasons to start earlier and persist longer.

"This trend is likely to continue in 2019 given the current conditions, climate outlook, and with a delayed start to the wet season likely."

The areas most exposed to bushfires are forested areas along the coast south of Rockhampton down to the NSW border, inland areas in the south of the state, a small area west of Mackay and in the south-west of Cape York.

Normal fire potential is expected for all other parts of Queensland.

The warning came as firefighters warned of a "long and busy" season that could bring an increased bushfire potential to some parts of the state.

Acting Fire Commissioner Mike Wassing agreed Queensland was likely to have an earlier start and a later finish to bushfire season.

"While conditions for this bushfire season are not looking the same as the 2018-19 season at this time, QFES will continue to prepare and plan for whatever mother nature throws at us," he said.

"We've noted with caution that the current rainfall and temperature outlooks show an increased likelihood of warmer and dryer conditions during bushfire season.

"People should familiarise themselves with bushfire warnings and where to access important information they may need during emergencies."

The Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre's 2018 report had warned of the same "above normal fire potential".

"These [2018] bushfires were the result of long term climate drivers - a lack of rainfall along the coast had led to drier soils and hotter daytime temperatures," the report said.

"During the bushfires there were a series of low pressure systems over south eastern Australia that drove a strong westerly air flow.

"These systems brought hot dry winds from central Australia right to the Queensland coast and resulted in record temperatures and forest fire danger indices."

Emergency Services Minister Craig Crawford has still not released a report he ordered into the devastating fires.

He said the report was being considered and "a whole-of-government response will be provided as soon as possible".

LNP fire spokesman Lachlan Millar said Mr Crawford was sitting on the report when it should be released to ensure communities could be better prepared for the season ahead.

"Last year more than a million hectares were destroyed during a fortnight of fires that devastated parts of Queensland unaccustomed to bushfires of that scale," Mr Millar said.

"I share the concerns many Queenslanders hold about land management practices to control fuel loads, how our national parks are managed, and what landholders want to do to protect their property and livestock.

"Instead of keeping the report under lock and key, there must be transparency to guarantee issues raised have been addressed and Queensland is not approaching the 2019 fire season without learning from past mistakes."

urn:contentItem:5B9X-NTW1-F0J6-J31S-00000-00Crews face fight on 93 fronts to keep people, property safe on horror days2014-01-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Crews face fight on 93 fronts to keep people, property safe on horror daysBUSHFIRE DANGERAlex McConachie, Georgina Mitchell with Esther Han

At least three properties were destroyed by an out-of-control forest fire in Minnimbah, near Wagga Wagga, on Sunday.

The Rural Fire Service issued an emergency warning for the Humula, Carabost and Little Billabong areas after a south-westerly wind change in the afternoon put 30 homes "under immediate threat" from a "quickly and erratically" burning fire.

The Minnimbah fire was the most severe of about 50 fires sparked by lightning strikes on Saturday night. More than 900 firefighters battled 93 active fires across the state on the weekend, RFS spokesman Joel Kursawe said.

Minnimbah residents evacuated mid-afternoon amid deteriorating weather conditions. No injuries or fatalities were reported.

Flames crowned to more than 500 metres as the fire burnt more than 8000 hectares of bush, including 520 hectares of Murragoldrie state forest and pine plantation.

More than 200 firefighters were still tackling the blaze into the evening, aided by two skycrane helicopters and other aircraft.

Riverina Rural Fire Service's James Smith said firefighters were "as confident as we can be" their new containment lines would create a major break to the southern and western sides of the fire before an expected wind change at midnight swung the fire around.

The RFS also issued an emergency warning for Ravensworth residents near Singleton at 6pm on Sunday after multiple, fast-moving grass fires tore through areas around Hebden Road.

"It is too late to leave. Seek shelter now from the heat of the fire," the alert read. An emergency warning was also issued for residents of Trunkey, near Bathurst, as the Hells Hole fire burned out of control in the Copperhannia National Park area.

Another major forest fire at Redbank, near Bathurst, was proving difficult to control, scorching through 300 hectares, including a radiata pine plantation. More than 60 firefighters used heavy machinery and water bombing aircraft to reduce its ferocity.

Firefighters were also building containment lines to control a scrub fire at Minjary, between Canberra and Wagga Wagga, which by Sunday afternoon burnt 2675 hectares.

At least 10 homes were destroyed in the Grampians region of Victoria. A fire in the northern parts of the Grampians National Park forced the evacuation of tourists and residents in Halls Gap.

PHOTO: Going into battle: A fire truck heads towards a massive fire that caused an emergency warning to be issued after a wind change put 30 homes at risk in villages near Wagga Wagga on Sunday. Photo: Les Smith

urn:contentItem:5RB7-2RX1-DYG0-92CY-00000-00VIC:Total fire ban issued for Vic on Saturday2018-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Total fire ban issued for Vic on SaturdayMELBOURNE Jan 4

  A total fire ban has been issued across the entire state of Victoria this Saturday amid extreme temperatures and Melbourne's hottest day in almost two years.
   No fires may be lit in the open air for the entire day, with the CFA advising residents living in fire-prone areas to activate their bushfire plans.


   Melbourne is expected to swelter through its hottest day in almost two years on Saturday, with the mercury expected to tip 41C in the city and northerly winds up to 40km/h.
   It's the hottest day the city has experienced since January 13, 2016, when temperatures soared to 42.2C.
   Temperatures are also expected to soar elsewhere in the state on Saturday - with Geelong and Bendigo expecting a high of 42C and Avalon, Echuca and Warracknabeal expecting 43C.
   Following the scorching start to the month, Melbourne and Victoria could expect a hotter January than average, Bureau of Meteorology duty forecaster Chris Godfred told AAP on Thursday.
   Last summer, Melbourne only reached a maximum of 38.2C.
   Mr Godfred says Melbourne residents can expect a warm day again on Monday, followed by a cool change in the early afternoon, with the "odd shower" coming through.
   Life Saving Victoria has warned beachgoers of potential dangers following four drowning deaths along the state's coastline since Christmas Day.
   Lifesaving operations manager Greg Scott says vulnerable swimmers need to choose a sheltered spot and also warned of rips being the number one beach hazard.
   ?Never swim alone and don?t over-estimate your ability, it?s just not worth it,'" he said in a statement.
   He said anyone caught in a rip current should stay calm, conserve their energy and either call out for help, float with the current, which may return them to a shallow sandbank, or swim parallel to the beach, which may help swimmers escape the current.
   Campers, riders and bushwalkers have been urged to take care in national parks, reserves and state forests this Saturday, with bushfires and heat stress being key risks.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi urged people to check conditions before entering parks and forests, to stop and rest in the shade, drink water and head back immediately if someone becomes unwell.

urn:contentItem:5RB7-2RX1-DYG0-9299-00000-00VIC:Melbourne set for hottest day in two years2018-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Melbourne set for hottest day in two yearsMELBOURNE Jan 4

  Melbourne residents have been urged to play it safe this Saturday as the city swelters through its hottest day in almost two years.
   With the mercury expected to hit 41C, Saturday will be the city's hottest day since January 13, 2016, when temperatures soared to 42.2C.


   Temperatures are also expected to soar elsewhere in the state on Saturday - with Geelong and Bendigo expecting a high of 42C and Avalon, Echuca and Warracknabeal expecting 43C.
   Following the scorching start to the month, Melbourne and Victoria could expect a hotter January than average, Bureau of Meteorology duty forecaster Chris Godfred told AAP on Thursday.
   Last summer, Melbourne only reached a maximum of 38.2C.
   Mr Godfred says Melbourne residents can expect a warm day again on Monday, followed by a cool change in the early afternoon, with the "odd shower" coming through.
   Life Saving Victoria has warned beachgoers of potential dangers following four drowning deaths along the state's coastline since Christmas Day.
   Lifesaving operations manager Greg Scott says vulnerable swimmers need to choose a sheltered spot and also warned of rips being the number one beach hazard.
   ?Never swim alone and don?t over-estimate your ability, it?s just not worth it,'" he said in a statement.
   He says anyone caught in a rip current should stay calm, conserve their energy and either call out for help, float with the current, which may return them to a shallow sandbank, or swim parallel to the beach, which may help swimmers escape the current.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria has also urged campers to follow safety rules if planning to light campfires this weekend.
   Melbourne can expect strong northerly winds up to 40km/h during the morning on Saturday, so campfires can potentially become bushfires and threaten lives and property, assistant chief fire officer Gill Metz says.
   ?Before you head out, check the weather conditions and if it is a Total Fire Ban do not have a campfire. It is illegal to light a campfire on a TFB day," she said in a statement.
   Anyone who does not follow strict campfire regulations can face a $476 on-the-spot fine or a penalty up to $15,872 if prosecuted in court.

urn:contentItem:5PDY-DP71-F0J6-J39G-00000-00'Above-normal' bushfire season forecast2017-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWS'Above-normal' bushfire season forecastNatalie Croxon

The latest seasonal bushfire outlook suggests Victoria could experience a more severe fire season this coming summer, with an earlier start in parts of the state.

The outlook shows there is currently 'above-normal' potential for bushfire across central Victoria.

Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said it indicated underlying dryness in parts of central Victoria and in the east of the state.

"While there is a lot of surface water, which means there will be grass growth and a healthy supply of water for crop growing, ground moisture has the potential to dry out quickly under dry and warm conditions," Mr Lapsley said.

But he said the level of fire risk in October to December would depend on rainfall this month.

The outlook report, prepared at a Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre and Australasian Fire and Emergency Services Authorities Council workshop, says there was below-average to record dry conditions across southern Australia from May to August.

The report says this has added to longer-term drying trend: Victoria has experienced below-average cooler season rainfall for 17 of the past 20 seasons.

"Very long-term deficiencies like these are not matched in the historical record, and have been associated with a marked increase in fire weather severity in the past decade," the report says.

It adds that climate change has seen temperatures climb to above-average.

The Bureau of Meteorology's outlook for September to November suggests there is a 65 to 75 per cent chance of exceeding the median maximum temperature this spring in central Victoria.

The bushfire report advises there is a risk of an early fire season in the northern and central western grain growing areas because of "good prospects for spring growth".

Mr Lapsley said pre-season briefings with emergency organisations and other relevant agencies would soon begin, with the CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria to bring forward their fire preparedness activities.

He said it was important the community also start thinking about their bushfire plans and use the spring months to prepare for the risk of fire.

urn:contentItem:5TCW-B831-JD3N-50P7-00000-00Street Watch2018-10-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisSTREETWATCHPg. 7Street Watch

1 ROWVILLE A disqualified driver caught more than four times the legal blood alcohol limit will face court. The 51-year-old Rowville man was pulled over after leaving the Burvale Hotel in Vermont South just before midnight on Saturday, September 22. Police spokesman Luke Zammit said officers saw the car move from its lane and decided to intercept it. After failing a preliminary breath test, the man was taken to Box Hill police station where he recorded an evidentiary breath test result of 0.207. After also being found to be driving with a disqualified licence, police impounded his vehicle for 30 days at a cost of $895. He will front court at a later date.

2 KNOX Police were out in force over the long weekend as part of operation scoreboard. Road Policing Command Acting Assistant Commissioner Neville Taylor said with so many people celebrating, it was a time of increased vulnerability and risk on the roads. "We want people to go out and have a great time, to enjoy the sportsmanship, celebrations and commiserations of what the grand final brings, but most importantly we want everyone using our roads to be safe," Mr Taylor said. Police from across Knox also conducted random alcohol and drug tests in backstreets.

3 KNOX Authorities are warning the community to keep an eye on campfires during the spring school holidays. Forest Fire Management Victoria assistant chief fire officer Jarrod Hayse said there had been 17 fires on public land across the region, with six caused by campfire negligence. "Most recently, a suspected unattended campfire caused a 3ha fire â€¦ luckily fire crews were able to contain the fire before it spread," Mr Hayse said. "Unattended campfires can lead to bushfires, placing the community and firefighters at risk, as well as potentially damaging the environment." He said officers would be patrolling parks and forests during the holiday period. "We're also asking people to be vigilant, and if they see a campfire that doesn't look right or is unattended, call 000," he said.

4 BORONIA An alleged serial thief accused of stealing from cars, a house and a Boronia shop has been arrested. Croydon police Sergeant Mark Manassa said officers spotted the man walking on Mt Dandenong Rd in Croydon during a routine patrol just after 8.30am on Wednesday, September 26. He was arrested and found with stolen items including iPads, clothing, tools and wallets from a series of overnight robberies from cars in Croydon. Sgt Manassa said the man, in his 20s and of no fixed address, was wanted by Knox detectives and Boronia police for a prior house burglary in Knox and a shop theft in Boronia. He faced Melbourne Magistrates' Court later that night and was charged with multiple thefts and driving related offences. Sgt Manassa said the man was remanded to face court again on October 16.

urn:contentItem:5R8G-R5S1-F0JP-W0MD-00000-00Danger as harvest looms2017-12-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 40Danger as harvest loomsBy LYNDAL READING

VICTORIAN wine grape growers are in the box seat with shortages in key growing regions across the world.

However, a bushfire could wipe out a vineyard in minutes.

Wine Victoria and the Department of Environment Land Water and Planning recently met to manage planned burns and winegrape smoke taint.

Australian Wine Research Institute business development manager Mark Krstic said smoke taint was a massive problem in 2007 when losses were estimated at $200 to $300 million in Victoria.

He said there were also losses in 2003 and 2009.

"The combined cost is well over $400 million over those four years," he said. He said the key danger time for grapevines was between veraison and harvest, generally January to March.

"At this time the volatile phenols are taken up and it makes the wine unsaleable," Mr Krstic said.

"It has to go down the sink. We are definitely not going to release any tainted wine to customers." However, Mr Krstic said planned burns were vital to reduce the threat of bushfires.

"Sometimes we come up against flashpoints and it's a very complicated situation where there might be only one or two days where they can do a particular burn," he said.

Wine Victoria environment and viticulture chair Damien Sheehan from Mt Langi Ghiran winery said there was "always going to be some intersection" between the optimum time for controlled burns and for grape harvest.

"They tend to track together - if the grape harvest is going to be later then there tend to be later planned burns because the conditions are right," Mr Sheehan said.

Mr Sheehan said sometimes the harvest window was small. He said growers could harvest a little early to avoid smoke taint from planned burns, but there was the risk of "green character" and lack of sugar in the wine.

Deputy chief fire officer Darrin McKenzie said Forest Fire Management Victoria consulted with winegrowers at a regional level about the scheduling of planned burns.

"We take their feedback into account when determining when and where we burn,""We make every effort to conduct planned burns near vineyards only on days when weather conditions, such as wind direction, will minimise the impacts of smoke."

urn:contentItem:5XT0-V4K1-JD34-V45N-00000-00Watch and act, advice messages issued as bushfires burn out of control2019-12-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisWatch and act, advice messages issued as bushfires burn out of controlKyra Gillespie

Update, 5pm: ALMOST every south-west fire brigade has been deployed as several bushfires burn across the district.

The fires were started by a lightening storm on Friday night and have been exacerbated by wind conditions on Saturday, CFA public information officer Sharon Mifsud said.

"They've all started from the lightning that came through last night, there was a big band of lightning and with the wind picking up today that's sparked some of them up," she said.

"We've got four messages out for the fires at the moment. There's lots of crews out there at the moment and there's a fair bit of smoke in the area so there could be other fires in the landscapes as well.

"If people do see something that's not matching up with the VicEmergency app they can still call triple zero."

READ MORE: Firefighters battle 33 new fires after cool change brings lightning

No lives or properties have been reported lost.

Ms Mifsud said people should update their fire management plans.

"It's a good reminder for people to review their survival plans," she said.

"We have just about all our brigades out there at the moment, we've only held a couple back in case there's any new incidents.

"Forest fire management crews are out there as well.

"It's not like the fire is in one spot, they're all over the place which adds to the complexities."

CFA issued an advice message for Bessiebelle, Breakaway Creek, Homerton, Lake Condah and Macarthur at 3:44pm on Saturday:

"There is a bushfire at Millard Track, Lake Condah that is not yet under control.

"The bushfire is travelling from Lake Condah in a northerly direction towards Budj Bim (Mount Eccles).

"There is currently no threat to you, but you should plan for what you will do if the situation changes."

The next update is expected by 21/12/2019 07.50 pm or as the situation changes.

An advice message was also put in place at 1:15pm on Saturday for Bahgallah, Casterton, Dartmoor, Digby, Henty, Killara, Merino, Mocamboro and Sandford for two out of control bushfires.

As of 4.53pm, three vehicles were responding to a 111-hectare bushfire at Digby-Strathdownie Road Killara not yet under control.

The bushfire was travelling from Digby-Strathdownie Road in a northerly direction towards Range Road.

As of 1.49pm, 29 vehicles responded to a small bushfire nearby.

There is currently no threat to communities.

As of 4.24pm there was an out of control bushfire 19 kilometres east of Dartmoor travelling from The Boulevard near Crawford River in a northerly direction towards Digby.

There is currently no threat to communities.

Earlier, 3pm: A watch and act message has been issued for residents in and around the Heywood area.

Drumborg, Greenwald, Heywood, Hotspur, Lyons, Milltown, Mount Richmond and West Sinclair have been warned of an out of control bushfire at Wrights Swamp Road, Cobboboonee National Park.

The bushfire is travelling from Wrights Swamp Road in a northerly direction towards Drumborg.

A CFA spokeswoman said the fire was near the Jackass Fern Gully and Fitzroy picnic and camping areas.

Forest Management Victoria issued the following warning at 2:47pm:

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

What you should do:

Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. If you are away from home, do not return. If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:

Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or to Heywood. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

Impacts in your area:

Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous. Bushfires can start spot fires and embers large distances ahead of the main fire. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. The next update is expected by 21/12/2019 06:50 pm or as the situation changes.

urn:contentItem:5H8X-J3N1-F0NT-H06D-00000-00Turnbull makes first trip to Jakarta2015-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisTurnbull makes first trip to JakartaAAP

PM to discuss investment, trade and countering violent extremism with President Joko Widodo.

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull will make his first official trip to Indonesia next week to meet with President Joko Widodo.

Relations with Australia's northern neighbour have been rocky this year, which has been dominated by diplomatic strife over the execution of Myuran Sukumaran and Andrew Chan in April.

Previously suspended ministerial visits resumed in July, which have paved the way for Mr Turnbull's trip.

The two leaders will discuss trade, investment and countering violent extremism.

The elevation of Mr Turnbull to the prime ministership has been welcomed within Indonesian government ranks.

Indonesia's ambassador to Australia Nadjib Riphat Kesoema last month described the relationship as being on an "upward trajectory".

He said Indonesia wanted to work with Australia on building resilience to withstand "short-term shocks".

In recent weeks, Australia has provided Indonesia with two aircraft to deal with the forest fire emergency.

Mr Turnbull will head to Berlin after the brief visit to Jakarta, where he will meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

He'll then attend his first G20 summit in Antalya, Turkey, before flying to Manila for the APEC leaders' meeting and Kuala Lumpur for the East Asia Summit.

urn:contentItem:5J5R-FSP1-F0J6-J21V-00000-00Fire region not yet cleared: TFS2016-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Fire region not yet cleared: TFSLUCY SWINNEN

GREAT work has been done to put out fires in the North-West but the region is not yet in the clear, according to Tasmania Fire Service acting deputy regional chief Steve Lowe.

"Most of the fires have moved into a contained status or a control status," Mr Lowe said.

"However, with increasing temperatures and Tasmania coming under the influence of high-pressure systems, winds will moderate and temperatures will rise. As the days warm up, ground fires may start to become more active again."

Aerial crew were able to survey the fire-affected areas on Friday and identified "plenty" of hotspots within the Mawbanna and Temma fires.

Rain over the past week has been helpful but not substantial.

Waratah and Yolla received eight millimetres of rain between 9am Thursday and 9am Friday while Smithton and Burnie received 12 millimetres in the same period.

About 75 New South Wales and South Australian fire crew left earlier than planned on Friday, as they were unable to fight the fires in the poor conditions.

There are about 170 firefighters based at Stanley with an additional 55 NSW and ACT firefighters due to arrive on Monday.

Crews will focus on fire hotspots across the North-West and West as well as strengthening containment lines on the Mawbanna fire, Mr Lowe said.

Activities at the Mersey forest fire will be scaled back.

urn:contentItem:5XRY-04T1-JD34-V1W1-00000-00Fire Danger Period restrictions in place2019-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisFire Danger Period restrictions in placeJessieAnne Gartlan

THE Fire Danger Period has been declared in the south of Ararat Rural City Monday December 16 after it came into effect in the northern half of the shire on December 2.

Country Fire Authority District 16 Operations Manager Bernie Fradd said despite positive winter rainfall across the region, grasslands and forest areas are quickly drying out.

"The rain may minimise the fire risk for just a day or two but it will not significantly delay fuels from drying out, so people should strongly consider the fire restrictions," Mr Fradd said.

"We encourage people who have conducted burn offs over the past month to check their piles, logs and stumps as heavy fuels can smoulder and reignite in summer even after it has been extinguished.

Mr Fradd said a study conducted on arson showed that more fires are caused by carelessness than criminal activity.

"It's about people really taking care and realizing fire is really dangerous here in Victoria," he said.

"We're asking people to take care and we'll be insuring any fires will be investigated and we'll refer them to the police where necessary.

Read more: Wimmera CFA and SES units receive grants for new equipment, vehicles

"While CFA and its partner agencies Parks Victoria, Forest Fire Management, and Emergency Management Victoria are doing everything we can to prepare for the bushfire season, we look to the community to use common sense and take responsibility for preventing fires."

Mr Fradd said if they haven't already done so, people need to clean up their properties.

"There is still time for people to clean up around their properties to ensure they are as safe as they can be," he said.

"People need to be aware that if using fire to clean up around their properties they need to register these on 1800 668 511. So far this year, out-of-control burn-offs and unregistered burn-offs have already caused unnecessary call-outs to for brigades.

"You should not burn off when winds are high or high winds are forecast - not only on the day of your burn but for the days afterwards.

"For information about burn-off restrictions specific to your area, consult your local council."

CFA does issue permits for a certain situations during the Fire Danger Period.

There are very strict conditions attached to these permits and the liability sits with the permit holder to ensure they always act safely.

During the Fire Danger Period fires cannot be lit in the open air without a written permit from the CFA or a Municipal Fire Prevention Officer.

Read more: Police industrial action across Western Victoria

FDPs are based on local conditions and take into account fuel moisture, fuel loads, grassland curing, weather and rainfall.

Fire Danger Period information and restrictions are published here.

Victorians can find out "Can I or Can't I?" information here or by calling VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

All burn-offs should be registered with the VicFire Burn-off notification line on 1800 668 511.

Fire Danger Period information:

A written permit is required to burn off grass, undergrowth, weeds or other vegetation during the FDP. This permit may be issued by the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer or the CFA District Office. Please check with your municipality in the first instance. Lighting a fire in the open without a permit is an offence and can bring a penalty of over $19,000 and/or 12 months imprisonment. Barbecues and fires for cooking and warmth do not require a permit, but must be lit in properly constructed fireplaces. The use of an incinerator, chainsaw or lawn mower, welding or grinding equipment and vehicles that come in contact with vegetation and machinery with an internal combustion/heat engine are permitted provided conditions are followed. Farmers can find legal guidelines and practical advice at cfa.vic.gov.au/plan-prepare/farms - this information is important especially for new farmers, bush block owners or hobby farmers. A Total Fire Ban declaration means no fires can be lit for the declared district for that day unless there is a specific exemption or special permit issued. This applies irrespective of the Fire Restriction status for a given municipality. Further details at cfa.vic.gov.au/warnings-restrictions/can/. urn:contentItem:5P9R-SYH1-JD34-V0R8-00000-00Asthmatics beware: this smoke's here for a few days longer | Gallery2017-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Asthmatics beware: this smoke's here for a few days longer | GalleryMel Davis

Smoke on the water...

This week residents of the Nambucca begrudgingly left the warmth of their blankets to find themselves enveloped in a blanket of a different kind.

A thick layer of smoke covered the valley on Monday morning, obscuring visibility and making breathing difficult for some.

The wild, dry and cool weather over the weekend ran local firefighters ragged, as they were repeatedly called to put out a series of forest fires throughout the valley.

But Lower North Coast zone manager for the Rural Fire Service, Superintendent Lachlann Ison said the main smoky culprit was a forest fire at Bellbucca Road within the Bellingen shire.

That fire was 'still well and truly going' on Monday, after evading Forest Corporation NSW and RFS firefighters' best efforts over the weekend.

"We finally got to a point where we could counter it, but we're in a holding pattern until that weather pattern changes and we get significant rain," Superintendent Ison said.

The fire near Oakes has chewed through 2183 hectares of state forest, but has now been controlled.

The gusty south-westerlies over the weekend, which reached a peak of 57km/hr according to the Bureau of Meterology, blew the smoke from the Bellingen fire towards the Nambucca Valley.

The Bureau of Meteorology said that the south-westerlies have abated for now and been replaced by milder northerly winds.

However significant rain is still not on the forecast, with the earliest real chance of a shower happening on Sunday.

The North Coast Public Health Unit advises people to consider their health while smoke from bushfires and hazard reduction burning is affecting air quality.

These particles can cause a variety of health problems, like itchy or burning eyes, throat irritation or a runny nose.

The smoke could also exaggerate existing conditions such as asthma, bronchitis and emphysema.

Director of the North Coast Public Health Unit, Paul Corben urged at-risk locals to stay indoors as much as possible.

urn:contentItem:5TBD-6M41-F0J6-J1KW-00000-00Axedale P.S oval designated as a bushfire place of last resort2018-09-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisAxedale P.S oval designated as a bushfire place of last resortAnthony Pinda

The City of Greater Bendigo has designated the Axedale P.S oval as a bushfire place of last resort for the upcoming fire danger period.

COGB director health and wellbeing Vicky Mason said the location met the approvals for the 2018/2019 fire danger period and was supported by the school community.

"The community needs to be very aware that designated bushfire places of last resort should only be used if all other plans have failed," Ms Mason said.

"The Axedale site is the school oval only. No buildings are involved and residents cannot expect anyone including emergency services to be present."

RELATED: Summer's fire danger period could be long and active as forecasts suggest warm, dry conditions to continue

Ms Mason said bushfire places of last resort were a final option for people to shelter in scenarios where all other plans had failed.

"They consist of a piece of open ground and should not be considered as places to relocate when leaving early," she said.

"Safety and survival cannot be guaranteed at these sites as support services will not be provided as these locations offer minimum protection against radiant heat and embers as they are purely a piece of open ground.

RELATED: Forest Fire Management Vic to recruit additional personnel for this year's fire season in the Murray Goldfields

"They are a place of last resort, in bushfire emergencies only, that may assist people when there is imminent threat of bushfire and they have no plan, or their planned options are not possible.

"On hot dry windy days, leaving the area early before there is any chance of fire activity, including along your travel path is always the safest option.

"There are no provisions at bushfire places of last resort for people and their pets or animals so having a well prepared fire plan around a more suitable location is a much better option. These locations are designed for when plans have failed to provide last resort option to survive a fire that comes with no guarantees."

Centro Lansell - Lansell Plaza shopping Centre car park, Calder Hwy Kangaroo Flat

Queen Elizabeth Oval, View Street Bendigo

Canterbury Park car park and events area, Simpsons Road Eaglehawk

North Bendigo Showgrounds, Holmes Road, Bendigo

Maiden Gully Primary School, basketball courts, Carolyn Way, Maiden Gully

Lord's Raceway, McIvor Highway, Junortoun

Strathfieldsaye Primary School playing fields, Uxbridge Street, Strathfieldsaye

Dower Park, Station Street, Kangaroo Flat

Redesdale Recreation Reserve Oval

Heathcote Holy Rosary Primary School Oval

Visit the CFA website for information on how to develop a fire and emergency plan and go to https://www.cfa.vic.gov.au/plan-prepare/neighbourhood-safer-places/ for information on last resort locations.

urn:contentItem:5XDB-9041-JD34-V3CC-00000-00The new bushfire reality we should all be preparing for2019-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 5The new bushfire reality we should all be preparing forHayley Elg

Climate change is bringing longer and hotter summers, meaning Australians are faced with a new bushfire reality - and we are already feeling the effects.

Around the world bushfires are burning and destroying landscapes and people's lives, for example in California, while there have also been recent devastating fires in Queensland and New South Wales. Last year dozens of fires broke out in the Ballarat region, including four major fires, with the Mt Clear fire igniting in April.

Climate modelling reveals that in south east Australia the severity and extent of the fire season is likely to increase, with less rainfall and hotter and drier conditions creating ideal fire conditions.

In the past climate shifts have occurred over thousands of years, but with increasing greenhouse gas emissions, the change we are currently experiencing is occurring within about 100 years - so rapidly that wildlife and natural vegetation are struggling to adapt.

An expert's opinion Creswick-based Melbourne University associate professor at the School of Ecosystem and Forest Sciences, Kevin Tolhurst, said one impact of climate change was more frequent and severe bushfires, but the level of severity would be determined by how they are managed.

Professor Tolhurst has spent his career studying bushfires and their behaviours. He said fire in the landscape had always occurred and was a way nature re-balanced itself. Though fire is often associated with negative impacts for wildlife, vegetation and humans, it can also be beneficial.

He said burning off was a strategy utilised by Indigenous Australians, who extensively used fire in the landscape before European settlement. Though fires no longer travel as freely as they did back then with houses, farms and roads built across the landscape and more ignition sources like vehicles and power lines within it, there are still valuable lessons to learn.

"Early season burning reduces the extent of wildfires in the landscape but also the amount of greenhouse gases being produced," he said.

"By putting more planned burning in the landscape it is advantageous both to the plants and animals being able to adapt to new environments, but also potentially reducing the amount of greenhouse gases produced because the amount of greenhouse gases released from major fires is much more than what is released from lower intensity planned burns."

Related coverage: Understanding fire behaviour could help keep you safe

Related coverage: Experts call for 'bold and ambitious' targets from government to reach zero emissions by 2050

Though fires are needed to clear undergrowth vegetation and to promote seed germination and new growth, Professor Tolhurst said communities and authorities were able to influence just how much of an impact more regular fires as a result of climate change would have.

"Fires are inevitable and with climate change, we can expect more of them," he said. "We're going to see more fire in the landscape but what that fire looks like is partly up to us to determine."

While fire suppression is important, Professor Tolhurst believes allowing more fire in the landscape in order to reduce fuel loads at times when the impact will be minimal is important.

"Low intensity fires reduce fuel loads in a more gradual and dispersed fashion and they are not as destructive," he said.

Professor Tolhurst said the idea that fires could be controlled purely by suppression was a "fool's dream", rather, we should be investing more in preparing for fires, from building and designing houses to be more fire resistant to better managing fuel loads across the landscape.

"The major focus should be on using more fire in the landscape to reduce the potential impact of fires burning out of control and impacting on communities and various other assets in the landscape," he said.

He said people often viewed fire as a damaging process, but like rain, which can cause flooding, we can't live without it.

Helping community to adapt The Ballarat Renewable Energy and Zero Emissions (BREAZE) group will host the first in its series of public forums about adapting to climate change on the subject of bushfires.

With presentations from experts in bushfire management, the three-and-a-half hour forum will explore the nature of bushfire threats in the Ballarat region, emergency planning and actions that individuals and communities can take to protect themselves.

The aim of the forum is to explore the bushfire risk in Ballarat and build on residents' knowledge and understanding - from the necessity of having a comprehensive emergency plan, raising awareness that bushfires will become more frequent and intense and recognising that emergency services have plans in place that should be understood across the community.

Another focus will be on exploring how communities can adapt and strengthen infrastructure to cope with a new bushfire reality and how public infrastructure can be more accessible as places of refuge during bushfire emergencies.

Related coverage: Plans to help Ballarat mitigate climate change

Related coverage: 'It could happen here', frontline plea after New South Wales disaster

At the conclusion of the forum, BREAZE hopes to be able to provide the results in a readily available document on its website. It also hopes to provide a submission to the City of Ballarat's Municipal Emergency Planning Committee, to assist with the development of their updated emergency response plan next year.

Fire unpredictability Country Fire Authority West Region Manager of Community Safety Michael Boatman said global warming was increasing temperatures around the world and creating unprecedented fire events, including in Australia, where bushfires are becoming more intense and seasons are extending.

Related coverage: 2019-20 bushfire preparations well under way

Related coverage: Fire lookout observers still playing an important role in summer firefighting effort

Related coverage: Ballarat fire chiefs call to get prepared now

"This new reality needs to be understood and acknowledged as we develop our plans for dealing with fire risks and possible outcomes.

"In Victoria's west and central regions, rain has kept ground moisture relatively high, although it has the potential to dry out quickly under dry and warm conditions" Mr Boatman said.

"Although Victoria's traditional period of increased fire activity is in January and February, the outlook suggests there will be a level of unpredictability around when fires will occur over the summer period and how intense they are likely to be."

He urged people to ensure they prepare their properties prior to the fire season to minimise the chance of property damage in the event of a fire.

He said though the CFA and partner agencies Forest Fire Management, DELWP, Emergency Management Victoria and Parks Victoria were doing everything it could to prepare for the bushfire season, preventing fires also comes down to community using common sense and taking responsibility.

Preparing your property For BREAZE secretary Ian Rossiter and his wife Chrissy, moving to a rural residential property on the edge of Buninyong 25 years ago has provided them with abundant space to grow produce, impressive views, fresh air, proximity to wildlife and ample space for their grandchildren and pets to enjoy the great outdoors.

The couple had experience with bushfires prior to moving to the area but it was the Linton and Enfield bushfires in the 1990s that pushed them to plan for a large scale fire in their region.

Related coverage: Why being prepared for the worst is Bridie's passion

They developed a fire survival plan using the resources provided by their local CFA five years ago and have activated it each bushfire season.

The decision as to whether to stay and defend their home or to evacuate is becoming more complex with grandchildren staying and needing to move pets, while travelling from their home on days with high temperatures and winds sees them plan for their pets and ensuring they travel with protective apparel in case they encounter wildfires on the road.

Their basic kit contains cotton coveralls, goggles, cotton hats, face masks, gloves, socks and leather boots. They also prepare bags with personal items they would need if their home were lost including toiletries, legal documents scanned onto a data stick, phone charges and a change of clothes.

"[People] might consider this overkill but last bushfire season, we enacted our Fire Survival Plan to defend our property four times between November and March for fire outbreaks in forests and plantations within four kilometres of our home," Mr Rossiter said.

Preparing for an ember attack is well rehearsed - removing all flammable materials, cars and gas cylinders away from the house, blocking down pipes and filling spouts and the bath with water, strategically placing mops and filled buckets of water around the house, turning off mains gas and connecting a garden hose internally to the laundry taps.

They also have an escape car at the ready and contact family and neighbours about their plans.

The department working year round to mitigate bushfire risk Tony English, Deputy Chief Fire Officer Grampians Region, said Victoria was one of the most bushfire prone environments in the world.

He said Forest Fire Management Victoria crews combined planned burning with other fuel reduction techniques like slashing and mowing as well as maintaining fuel breaks, infrastructure including access roads, fire dams and lookout towers to manage bushfire risk and keep communities safe.

The department also prepares and positions firefighters and aircraft across the state to ensure a rapid response to bushfires when they begin.

"By working together and continually researching fire and its interaction with the environment, we can be better prepared as each bushfire season approaches."

The free BREAZE forum will be hosted on Sunday, November 10 from 1.00 pm at Ballarat Mechanics Institute. Tickets and more information available at: thenewbushfirereality.eventbrite.com.

urn:contentItem:5TWM-JV01-DY19-C21C-00000-00This gender reveal burnout ended up costing a lot more than planned2018-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisThis gender reveal burnout ended up costing a lot more than plannedElliot Williams

Andrew Coleman's ute took centre stage at his half-sister's gender reveal party. But the video posted to Facebook ended up with the cops, who weren't happy.

A Canberra uncle's gender reveal burnout has burnt a significant hole in his pocket, after he received more than $1500 in fines for the stunt that took place in May.

Andrew William Coleman, 24, of Gordon, pleaded guilty to aggravated dangerous driving, causing an environmental nuisance and not providing his details when questioned by police.

Coleman received $1700 in fines, a 12-month good behaviour bond and an automatic licence disqualification of 12 months.

He was arrested after ACT Policing received information from their NSW counterparts when footage of the burnout surfaced.

Coleman performed the burnout in Ampt Place, Theodore, as part of a gender reveal party for his pregnant half-sister.

There has been a growing trend of revealing a baby's gender with a burnout, which emits either blue or pink smoke.

In the footage, a green ute is visible in the street while the pregnant woman is in a driveway facing away from the vehicle.

Coleman then begins to rev the engine loudly as blue smoke quickly engulfs the street and squeals of excitement are heard off camera.

The ute completes at least two 360-degree turns before being hidden by the smoke. Court documents showed the police estimated the plume of smoke to be at least 15 metres wide and reach 20 metres into the air.

Loud revving continues to be heard in the video after the ute disappears and more smoke is created.

The documents showed police believed Coleman caused the ute to have a sustained loss of traction while there were onlookers standing nearby and up to five cars parked in the vicinity.

The charge of aggravated dangerous driving was applied as there was a pedestrian standing within metres of the ute while Coleman performed the burnout.

Four black tyre marks are visible on the road as the smoke clears in the video. Coleman then begins to slowly drive up the driveway towards onlookers, including his half-sister, while continuing to rev the engine with more smoke emitted.

The court documents said police officers interviewed a nearby resident, who told them the noise of the burnout had woken her young children and her house had been filled with smoke. She said washing hung outside had to be re-washed as it had been filled with smoke residue.

Coleman was identified as the driver by three witnesses who were at the gender reveal party, including his father. When Coleman was later questioned by police he refused to provide the details of the driver.

Earlier this year a gender reveal party gone wrong caused a 19,000-hectare forest fire in the US state of Arizona. In that instance an explosive substance was used to shower coloured powder into the air, but also ignited the blaze.

urn:contentItem:5SNM-SFP1-JD34-V2FY-00000-00WE SAY: Fire work helped with swag of new recruits2018-06-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisWE SAY: Fire work helped with swag of new recruitsEditorial

Heavy frosts and fog and now we're getting a bit of rain mixed in with the winter cold.

All that most of us can think about now is keeping warm, keeping the kids (and the dog) dry and hoping a bit of sunshine peeks through the gloom so there's a chance of giving the lawnmower a run at the weekend.

At least the rain we've had in recent weeks has consigned the dust bowl created by the arid March to the past, for now, and there might be a decent fill in the water tank for when it eventually warms up again.

We on the Border certainly get all four seasons, something that helps make the region such a wonderful place to live.

But in the cold, just past the shortest day of the winter solstice, there is one thing that you would be hard-pressed to think about.

That is unless it's in you line of work.

And that's the annual fire danger season, which many professional and volunteer firefighters always have in sight.

This threat is with us each and every year of course.

It's simply a fact of life that we must always do what we can to be prepared, both in terms of keeping our properties clear and in making sure we have a fire plan to ensure we leave before a fast-encroaching fire is upon us.

Despite summer being so far away, we should at least be mindful of the fact things will get warmer and, eventually, a lot drier.

It is the same for those who go out and fight fires, who have the job of making sure burn-offs are done in readiness in order to minimise the dangers.

A key organisation involved in this demanding work is Forest Fire Management, which is always planning for the most effective way to carry out its vitally important role.

As part of that, it has just announced it wants to hear from those who might be interested in a career as forest or fire operations officers. That involves 28 positions and, significantly, 12 of the jobs are in the Hume region.

As Ovens district manager Jarrod Hayse points out, diversity is the goal for its firefighting team.

One aim is to continue to work towards a better balance of the ratio between men and women in the ranks, even with a record 112 female forest firefighters in its ranks across Victoria last summer. We wholeheartedly support this goal and the overall recruitment drive.

urn:contentItem:5KG9-V761-DY19-C3X4-00000-00Fire puts mountain bike centre in danger2016-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisFire puts mountain bike centre in dangerDaniel Cherny

Rio de Janeiro: A forest fire on Monday placed the Olympic mountain biking venue in jeopardy, but games organisers insist the threat has passed.Spectators arrived at the Olympic hockey centre late on Monday afternoon to find smoke and ash blowing over the venue ahead of the women's quarter-final between Great Britain and Spain.The conditions were a result of a fire which a Rio 2016 spokeswoman said started about 4pm near the Deodoro sports complex, home of the equestrian, rugby sevens, shooting, BMX, mountain biking, canoeing, kayaking, women's basketball and modern pentathlon at these Games.The spokeswoman said that the fire became more aggressive, placing the mountain bike centre in danger less than a week before it hosts the cross-country races of this year's calendar.But according to the spokeswoman, a change of wind direction moved the fire out of harm's way. She said there had been no injuries as a result of the fire, with firefighters continuing in their attempts to extinguish it as of late on Monday night.The close shave followed a similar incident last week, when a nearby blaze endangered the rugby sevens competition.Brazil had almost a quarter of a million forest fires last year as the country suffered through a drought.

Despite the difficult surroundings, Britain progressed to the last four of the hockey tournament, beating the Spaniards 3-1.Britain's semi-final opponent on Wednesday will be New Zealand, who eliminated Australia earlier on Monday.

urn:contentItem:5RYS-R981-JD3N-524K-00000-00At this derby, losers are left crushed2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisBACKPADDOCKPg. 23At this derby, losers are left crushed

FORGET your glamorous, hi-octane grand prix at Albert Park on the weekend - Keith, South Australia is where all the real motorsport action was.

The Keith Diesel and Dirt Derby was on last weekend, entertaining a huge crowd with displays of tractor power, a header demolition derby and even a secret meeting between Donald Trump and Kim Jong-un which was brought to a swift end by an army tank which crushed their Mercedes limos. (pictured below).

It was all part of the fun at the Derby which included jet boat racing and a tractor pull.

Jenny Aitken from the organising committee said it was a roaring success, with 11,500 people turning out to see the action.

In what is Australia's only header demolition derby the aim is pretty simple - to destroy your opponents' headers and be the last one standing. Aaron Prettejohn from Keith won the event in his Claas header out of a field of 18.

A warm glow for Mr Burns BACK Paddock has often featured people whose names match their jobs but we didn't realise there is a term for it: it's called nominative determinism, the hypothesis that people tend to gravitate towards areas of work that fit their names.

It apparently explains why you get dentists called Dr Toothman or weather presenters called Amy Freeze. The latest example we have come across of nominative determinism is one of the district managers for Forest Fire Management Victoria - Wesley Burns. True.

Only one word for this job VISITORS to Melbourne may have noticed the city's most-famous landmark, Flinders Street Station, has been given a spruce-up including a change in colour. They may also be interested to learn that as part of the clean-up, more than 10 tonnes of pigeon poo have been removed from the station's iconic dome. That's a lot of manure. It's the first time in 100 years the giant pigeon coop has been cleaned.

Back Paddock wonders what some poor bugger must have done to be given that job.

Thieves got clean away THE crime rate in Victoria may have gone down, but Seymour is still a crime hotspot. Police reported the theft of three large towels stolen from a clothesline in the backyard of a Monash Drive house, recently. "It appears the towels were targeted as other items on the line were left untouched," the Seymour police said.Could it be a case of money laundering perhaps?
