urn:contentItem:5SNM-SFP1-JD34-V2KJ-00000-00WE SAY: Fire work helped with swag of new recruits2018-06-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisWE SAY: Fire work helped with swag of new recruitsEditorial

Heavy frosts and fog and now we're getting a bit of rain mixed in with the winter cold.

All that most of us can think about now is keeping warm, keeping the kids (and the dog) dry and hoping a bit of sunshine peeks through the gloom so there's a chance of giving the lawnmower a run at the weekend.

At least the rain we've had in recent weeks has consigned the dust bowl created by the arid March to the past, for now, and there might be a decent fill in the water tank for when it eventually warms up again.

We on the Border certainly get all four seasons, something that helps make the region such a wonderful place to live.

But in the cold, just past the shortest day of the winter solstice, there is one thing that you would be hard-pressed to think about.

That is unless it's in you line of work.

And that's the annual fire danger season, which many professional and volunteer firefighters always have in sight.

This threat is with us each and every year of course.

It's simply a fact of life that we must always do what we can to be prepared, both in terms of keeping our properties clear and in making sure we have a fire plan to ensure we leave before a fast-encroaching fire is upon us.

Despite summer being so far away, we should at least be mindful of the fact things will get warmer and, eventually, a lot drier.

It is the same for those who go out and fight fires, who have the job of making sure burn-offs are done in readiness in order to minimise the dangers.

A key organisation involved in this demanding work is Forest Fire Management, which is always planning for the most effective way to carry out its vitally important role.

As part of that, it has just announced it wants to hear from those who might be interested in a career as forest or fire operations officers. That involves 28 positions and, significantly, 12 of the jobs are in the Hume region.

As Ovens district manager Jarrod Hayse points out, diversity is the goal for its firefighting team.

One aim is to continue to work towards a better balance of the ratio between men and women in the ranks, even with a record 112 female forest firefighters in its ranks across Victoria last summer. We wholeheartedly support this goal and the overall recruitment drive.

urn:contentItem:5XDB-9041-JD34-V3F7-00000-00The new bushfire reality we should all be preparing for2019-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEThe new bushfire reality we should all be preparing forHayley Elg

Climate change is bringing longer and hotter summers, meaning Australians are faced with a new bushfire reality - and we are already feeling the effects.

Around the world bushfires are burning and destroying landscapes and people's lives, for example in California, while there have also been recent devastating fires in Queensland and New South Wales. Last year dozens of fires broke out in the Ballarat region, including four major fires, with the Mt Clear fire igniting in April.

Climate modelling reveals that in south east Australia the severity and extent of the fire season is likely to increase, with less rainfall and hotter and drier conditions creating ideal fire conditions.

In the past climate shifts have occurred over thousands of years, but with increasing greenhouse gas emissions, the change we are currently experiencing is occurring within about 100 years - so rapidly that wildlife and natural vegetation are struggling to adapt.

An expert's opinion Creswick-based Melbourne University associate professor at the School of Ecosystem and Forest Sciences, Kevin Tolhurst, said one impact of climate change was more frequent and severe bushfires, but the level of severity would be determined by how they are managed.

Professor Tolhurst has spent his career studying bushfires and their behaviours. He said fire in the landscape had always occurred and was a way nature re-balanced itself. Though fire is often associated with negative impacts for wildlife, vegetation and humans, it can also be beneficial.

He said burning off was a strategy utilised by Indigenous Australians, who extensively used fire in the landscape before European settlement. Though fires no longer travel as freely as they did back then with houses, farms and roads built across the landscape and more ignition sources like vehicles and power lines within it, there are still valuable lessons to learn.

"Early season burning reduces the extent of wildfires in the landscape but also the amount of greenhouse gases being produced," he said.

"By putting more planned burning in the landscape it is advantageous both to the plants and animals being able to adapt to new environments, but also potentially reducing the amount of greenhouse gases produced because the amount of greenhouse gases released from major fires is much more than what is released from lower intensity planned burns."

Related coverage: Understanding fire behaviour could help keep you safe

Related coverage: Experts call for 'bold and ambitious' targets from government to reach zero emissions by 2050

Though fires are needed to clear undergrowth vegetation and to promote seed germination and new growth, Professor Tolhurst said communities and authorities were able to influence just how much of an impact more regular fires as a result of climate change would have.

"Fires are inevitable and with climate change, we can expect more of them," he said. "We're going to see more fire in the landscape but what that fire looks like is partly up to us to determine."

While fire suppression is important, Professor Tolhurst believes allowing more fire in the landscape in order to reduce fuel loads at times when the impact will be minimal is important.

"Low intensity fires reduce fuel loads in a more gradual and dispersed fashion and they are not as destructive," he said.

Professor Tolhurst said the idea that fires could be controlled purely by suppression was a "fool's dream", rather, we should be investing more in preparing for fires, from building and designing houses to be more fire resistant to better managing fuel loads across the landscape.

"The major focus should be on using more fire in the landscape to reduce the potential impact of fires burning out of control and impacting on communities and various other assets in the landscape," he said.

He said people often viewed fire as a damaging process, but like rain, which can cause flooding, we can't live without it.

Helping community to adapt The Ballarat Renewable Energy and Zero Emissions (BREAZE) group will host the first in its series of public forums about adapting to climate change on the subject of bushfires.

With presentations from experts in bushfire management, the three-and-a-half hour forum will explore the nature of bushfire threats in the Ballarat region, emergency planning and actions that individuals and communities can take to protect themselves.

The aim of the forum is to explore the bushfire risk in Ballarat and build on residents' knowledge and understanding - from the necessity of having a comprehensive emergency plan, raising awareness that bushfires will become more frequent and intense and recognising that emergency services have plans in place that should be understood across the community.

Another focus will be on exploring how communities can adapt and strengthen infrastructure to cope with a new bushfire reality and how public infrastructure can be more accessible as places of refuge during bushfire emergencies.

Related coverage: Plans to help Ballarat mitigate climate change

Related coverage: 'It could happen here', frontline plea after New South Wales disaster

At the conclusion of the forum, BREAZE hopes to be able to provide the results in a readily available document on its website. It also hopes to provide a submission to the City of Ballarat's Municipal Emergency Planning Committee, to assist with the development of their updated emergency response plan next year.

Fire unpredictability Country Fire Authority West Region Manager of Community Safety Michael Boatman said global warming was increasing temperatures around the world and creating unprecedented fire events, including in Australia, where bushfires are becoming more intense and seasons are extending.

Related coverage: 2019-20 bushfire preparations well under way

Related coverage: Fire lookout observers still playing an important role in summer firefighting effort

Related coverage: Ballarat fire chiefs call to get prepared now

"This new reality needs to be understood and acknowledged as we develop our plans for dealing with fire risks and possible outcomes.

"In Victoria's west and central regions, rain has kept ground moisture relatively high, although it has the potential to dry out quickly under dry and warm conditions" Mr Boatman said.

"Although Victoria's traditional period of increased fire activity is in January and February, the outlook suggests there will be a level of unpredictability around when fires will occur over the summer period and how intense they are likely to be."

He urged people to ensure they prepare their properties prior to the fire season to minimise the chance of property damage in the event of a fire.

He said though the CFA and partner agencies Forest Fire Management, DELWP, Emergency Management Victoria and Parks Victoria were doing everything it could to prepare for the bushfire season, preventing fires also comes down to community using common sense and taking responsibility.

Preparing your property For BREAZE secretary Ian Rossiter and his wife Chrissy, moving to a rural residential property on the edge of Buninyong 25 years ago has provided them with abundant space to grow produce, impressive views, fresh air, proximity to wildlife and ample space for their grandchildren and pets to enjoy the great outdoors.

The couple had experience with bushfires prior to moving to the area but it was the Linton and Enfield bushfires in the 1990s that pushed them to plan for a large scale fire in their region.

Related coverage: Why being prepared for the worst is Bridie's passion

They developed a fire survival plan using the resources provided by their local CFA five years ago and have activated it each bushfire season.

The decision as to whether to stay and defend their home or to evacuate is becoming more complex with grandchildren staying and needing to move pets, while travelling from their home on days with high temperatures and winds sees them plan for their pets and ensuring they travel with protective apparel in case they encounter wildfires on the road.

Their basic kit contains cotton coveralls, goggles, cotton hats, face masks, gloves, socks and leather boots. They also prepare bags with personal items they would need if their home were lost including toiletries, legal documents scanned onto a data stick, phone charges and a change of clothes.

"[People] might consider this overkill but last bushfire season, we enacted our Fire Survival Plan to defend our property four times between November and March for fire outbreaks in forests and plantations within four kilometres of our home," Mr Rossiter said.

Preparing for an ember attack is well rehearsed - removing all flammable materials, cars and gas cylinders away from the house, blocking down pipes and filling spouts and the bath with water, strategically placing mops and filled buckets of water around the house, turning off mains gas and connecting a garden hose internally to the laundry taps.

They also have an escape car at the ready and contact family and neighbours about their plans.

The department working year round to mitigate bushfire risk Tony English, Deputy Chief Fire Officer Grampians Region, said Victoria was one of the most bushfire prone environments in the world.

He said Forest Fire Management Victoria crews combined planned burning with other fuel reduction techniques like slashing and mowing as well as maintaining fuel breaks, infrastructure including access roads, fire dams and lookout towers to manage bushfire risk and keep communities safe.

The department also prepares and positions firefighters and aircraft across the state to ensure a rapid response to bushfires when they begin.

"By working together and continually researching fire and its interaction with the environment, we can be better prepared as each bushfire season approaches."

The free BREAZE forum will be hosted on Sunday, November 10 from 1.00 pm at Ballarat Mechanics Institute. Tickets and more information available at: thenewbushfirereality.eventbrite.com.

urn:contentItem:5TWS-BF91-DY19-C0HN-00000-00This gender reveal burnout ended up costing a lot more than planned2018-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisThis gender reveal burnout ended up costing a lot more than plannedElliot Williams

Andrew Coleman's ute took centre stage at his half-sister's gender reveal party. But the video posted to Facebook ended up with the cops, who weren't happy.

A Canberra uncle's gender reveal burnout has burnt a significant hole in his pocket, after he received more than $1500 in fines for the stunt that took place in May.

Andrew William Coleman, 24, of Gordon, pleaded guilty to aggravated dangerous driving, causing an environmental nuisance and not providing his details when questioned by police.

Coleman received $1700 in fines, a 12-month good behaviour bond and an automatic licence disqualification of 12 months.

He was arrested after ACT Policing received information from their NSW counterparts when footage of the burnout surfaced.

Coleman performed the burnout in Ampt Place, Theodore, as part of a gender reveal party for his pregnant half-sister.

There has been a growing trend of revealing a baby's gender with a burnout, which emits either blue or pink smoke.

In the footage, a green ute is visible in the street while the pregnant woman is in a driveway facing away from the vehicle.

Coleman then begins to rev the engine loudly as blue smoke quickly engulfs the street and squeals of excitement are heard off camera.

The ute completes at least two 360-degree turns before being hidden by the smoke. Court documents showed the police estimated the plume of smoke to be at least 15 metres wide and reach 20 metres into the air.

Loud revving continues to be heard in the video after the ute disappears and more smoke is created.

The documents showed police believed Coleman caused the ute to have a sustained loss of traction while there were onlookers standing nearby and up to five cars parked in the vicinity.

The charge of aggravated dangerous driving was applied as there was a pedestrian standing within metres of the ute while Coleman performed the burnout.

Four black tyre marks are visible on the road as the smoke clears in the video. Coleman then begins to slowly drive up the driveway towards onlookers, including his half-sister, while continuing to rev the engine with more smoke emitted.

The court documents said police officers interviewed a nearby resident, who told them the noise of the burnout had woken her young children and her house had been filled with smoke. She said washing hung outside had to be re-washed as it had been filled with smoke residue.

Coleman was identified as the driver by three witnesses who were at the gender reveal party, including his father. When Coleman was later questioned by police he refused to provide the details of the driver.

Earlier this year a gender reveal party gone wrong caused a 19,000-hectare forest fire in the US state of Arizona. In that instance an explosive substance was used to shower coloured powder into the air, but also ignited the blaze.

Related coverage: Experts call for 'bold and ambitious' targets from government to reach zero emissions by 2050

Though fires are needed to clear undergrowth vegetation and to promote seed germination and new growth, Professor Tolhurst said communities and authorities were able to influence just how much of an impact more regular fires as a result of climate change would have.

"Fires are inevitable and with climate change, we can expect more of them," he said. "We're going to see more fire in the landscape but what that fire looks like is partly up to us to determine."

While fire suppression is important, Professor Tolhurst believes allowing more fire in the landscape in order to reduce fuel loads at times when the impact will be minimal is important.

"Low intensity fires reduce fuel loads in a more gradual and dispersed fashion and they are not as destructive," he said.

Professor Tolhurst said the idea that fires could be controlled purely by suppression was a "fool's dream", rather, we should be investing more in preparing for fires, from building and designing houses to be more fire resistant to better managing fuel loads across the landscape.

"The major focus should be on using more fire in the landscape to reduce the potential impact of fires burning out of control and impacting on communities and various other assets in the landscape," he said.

He said people often viewed fire as a damaging process, but like rain, which can cause flooding, we can't live without it.

Helping community to adapt The Ballarat Renewable Energy and Zero Emissions (BREAZE) group will host the first in its series of public forums about adapting to climate change on the subject of bushfires.

With presentations from experts in bushfire management, the three-and-a-half hour forum will explore the nature of bushfire threats in the Ballarat region, emergency planning and actions that individuals and communities can take to protect themselves.

The aim of the forum is to explore the bushfire risk in Ballarat and build on residents' knowledge and understanding - from the necessity of having a comprehensive emergency plan, raising awareness that bushfires will become more frequent and intense and recognising that emergency services have plans in place that should be understood across the community.

Another focus will be on exploring how communities can adapt and strengthen infrastructure to cope with a new bushfire reality and how public infrastructure can be more accessible as places of refuge during bushfire emergencies.

Related coverage: Plans to help Ballarat mitigate climate change

Related coverage: 'It could happen here', frontline plea after New South Wales disaster

At the conclusion of the forum, BREAZE hopes to be able to provide the results in a readily available document on its website. It also hopes to provide a submission to the City of Ballarat's Municipal Emergency Planning Committee, to assist with the development of their updated emergency response plan next year.

Fire unpredictability Country Fire Authority West Region Manager of Community Safety Michael Boatman said global warming was increasing temperatures around the world and creating unprecedented fire events, including in Australia, where bushfires are becoming more intense and seasons are extending.

Related coverage: 2019-20 bushfire preparations well under way

Related coverage: Fire lookout observers still playing an important role in summer firefighting effort

Related coverage: Ballarat fire chiefs call to get prepared now

"This new reality needs to be understood and acknowledged as we develop our plans for dealing with fire risks and possible outcomes.

"In Victoria's west and central regions, rain has kept ground moisture relatively high, although it has the potential to dry out quickly under dry and warm conditions" Mr Boatman said.

"Although Victoria's traditional period of increased fire activity is in January and February, the outlook suggests there will be a level of unpredictability around when fires will occur over the summer period and how intense they are likely to be."

He urged people to ensure they prepare their properties prior to the fire season to minimise the chance of property damage in the event of a fire.

He said though the CFA and partner agencies Forest Fire Management, DELWP, Emergency Management Victoria and Parks Victoria were doing everything it could to prepare for the bushfire season, preventing fires also comes down to community using common sense and taking responsibility.

Preparing your property For BREAZE secretary Ian Rossiter and his wife Chrissy, moving to a rural residential property on the edge of Buninyong 25 years ago has provided them with abundant space to grow produce, impressive views, fresh air, proximity to wildlife and ample space for their grandchildren and pets to enjoy the great outdoors.

The couple had experience with bushfires prior to moving to the area but it was the Linton and Enfield bushfires in the 1990s that pushed them to plan for a large scale fire in their region.

Related coverage: Why being prepared for the worst is Bridie's passion

They developed a fire survival plan using the resources provided by their local CFA five years ago and have activated it each bushfire season.

The decision as to whether to stay and defend their home or to evacuate is becoming more complex with grandchildren staying and needing to move pets, while travelling from their home on days with high temperatures and winds sees them plan for their pets and ensuring they travel with protective apparel in case they encounter wildfires on the road.

Their basic kit contains cotton coveralls, goggles, cotton hats, face masks, gloves, socks and leather boots. They also prepare bags with personal items they would need if their home were lost including toiletries, legal documents scanned onto a data stick, phone charges and a change of clothes.

"[People] might consider this overkill but last bushfire season, we enacted our Fire Survival Plan to defend our property four times between November and March for fire outbreaks in forests and plantations within four kilometres of our home," Mr Rossiter said.

Preparing for an ember attack is well rehearsed - removing all flammable materials, cars and gas cylinders away from the house, blocking down pipes and filling spouts and the bath with water, strategically placing mops and filled buckets of water around the house, turning off mains gas and connecting a garden hose internally to the laundry taps.

They also have an escape car at the ready and contact family and neighbours about their plans.

The department working year round to mitigate bushfire risk Tony English, Deputy Chief Fire Officer Grampians Region, said Victoria was one of the most bushfire prone environments in the world.

He said Forest Fire Management Victoria crews combined planned burning with other fuel reduction techniques like slashing and mowing as well as maintaining fuel breaks, infrastructure including access roads, fire dams and lookout towers to manage bushfire risk and keep communities safe.

The department also prepares and positions firefighters and aircraft across the state to ensure a rapid response to bushfires when they begin.

"By working together and continually researching fire and its interaction with the environment, we can be better prepared as each bushfire season approaches."

The free BREAZE forum will be hosted on Sunday, November 10 from 1.00 pm at Ballarat Mechanics Institute. Tickets and more information available at: thenewbushfirereality.eventbrite.com.

Climate change is bringing longer and hotter summers, meaning Australians are faced with a new bushfire reality - and we are already feeling the effects.

Around the world bushfires are burning and destroying landscapes and people's lives, for example in California, while there have also been recent devastating fires in Queensland and New South Wales. Last year dozens of fires broke out in the Ballarat region, including four major fires, with the Mt Clear fire igniting in April.

Climate modelling reveals that in south east Australia the severity and extent of the fire season is likely to increase, with less rainfall and hotter and drier conditions creating ideal fire conditions.

In the past climate shifts have occurred over thousands of years, but with increasing greenhouse gas emissions, the change we are currently experiencing is occurring within about 100 years - so rapidly that wildlife and natural vegetation are struggling to adapt.

An expert's opinion Creswick-based Melbourne University associate professor at the School of Ecosystem and Forest Sciences, Kevin Tolhurst, said one impact of climate change was more frequent and severe bushfires, but the level of severity would be determined by how they are managed.

Professor Tolhurst has spent his career studying bushfires and their behaviours. He said fire in the landscape had always occurred and was a way nature re-balanced itself. Though fire is often associated with negative impacts for wildlife, vegetation and humans, it can also be beneficial.

He said burning off was a strategy utilised by Indigenous Australians, who extensively used fire in the landscape before European settlement. Though fires no longer travel as freely as they did back then with houses, farms and roads built across the landscape and more ignition sources like vehicles and power lines within it, there are still valuable lessons to learn.

"Early season burning reduces the extent of wildfires in the landscape but also the amount of greenhouse gases being produced," he said.

"By putting more planned burning in the landscape it is advantageous both to the plants and animals being able to adapt to new environments, but also potentially reducing the amount of greenhouse gases produced because the amount of greenhouse gases released from major fires is much more than what is released from lower intensity planned burns."

urn:contentItem:5X1V-N341-JD34-V18M-00000-00Who needs to plan for bushfire and how to do it2019-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Who needs to plan for bushfire and how to do itExplainerJenny Noyes

Bushfires can be sudden and unpredictable. Preparations need to be known and understood by everyone, writes Jenny Noyes.

The bushfire crisis that has hit south-east Queensland and northern NSW has devastated communities - and is a wake-up call to residents across Australia. Fire authorities are urging families to sit down - today - and work out what they'd do in the event of a bushfire.

So how do you make a plan?

Do we all need a bushfire plan?

The need for a plan is a no-brainer for people living on fire-prone land but city-dwellers should also keep bushfire in mind when planning holidays and weekends away, says Rural Fire Service spokesman Ben Shepherd.

"Quite often we spend weeks or months organising a holiday but we won't spend an extra 40 minutes just discussing what we might do in the event that a bushfire threatens us."

As urban sprawl continues to creep into bushfire zones, experts warn that more people may need to plan for a bushfire in their backyard.

Sydney, for instance, has peri-urban areas where the suburbs encroach on national parks, such as around Lane Cove and Cronulla, says Dale Dominey-Howes, Professor of Hazard and Disaster Risk Sciences at the University of Sydney. Even in parts of the city's inner west, there are pockets that could be vulnerable to catching fire, he says.

Should I stay or should I go?

Leaving is the right decision for most people, and the only option advised on days with extreme and catastrophic fire danger - but it's not a fireproof plan, says Inspector Shepherd.

Why? Because fire won't always give you that choice.

The three main questions to think about when making a plan are: who is going to go, what you're going to take, and when you're going to go, he says.

But you also need to think about contingencies - a Plan B.

What if they can't leave, or what if their route is cut, or what if we're not together as a family unit? Does everybody in the household know what they're going to do?

What happens if the kids are home alone? Do they know what to do?

NSW fire authorities have launched a website - myfireplan.com.au - to help families talk through what they can do and work out a "fireproof" survival plan. Families are also encouraged to visit their local fire station and talk through any questions.

What do the fire ratings mean?

We've all seen the roadside fire danger rating dial, to which catastrophic was added after Black Saturday. It's based on the Forest Fire Danger Index (FFDI) which takes in forecast conditions - temperature, humidity, wind speed and dryness of the landscape.

When the danger rating is "catastrophic", no home can withstand the severity of the fire and people are encouraged to leave fire-prone areas before any fire has started.

At "extreme", it's only possible to defend homes that have been specially built to withstand fire.

At "severe", only if a home is well-prepared and the homeowner physically and mentally capable of defending it should they consider staying.

That's not to say firefighting is a walk in the park at lower levels, Inspector Shepherd warns. More homes have been lost in NSW at "very high" and "severe" fire danger than "extreme" and "catastrophic" days, which remain rare.

What else can you do now?

The NSW Rural Fire Service is powered by more than 70,000 volunteers, QFES has about 42,000, Victoria's Country Fire Association has almost 35,000, South Australia's Country Fire Service about 13,500, Tasmania has 5000 and Western Australia has about 2300. But they are increasingly stretched.

Professor Dominey-Howes suggests getting involved with your local volunteer fire service.

"That way, you're contributing to your community, getting to know other people, and you'll grow skills and knowledge that you'll take back to your home and share with your family and your network."

urn:contentItem:7X8F-KF00-YBDY-R274-00000-00IN BRIEF2009-12-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4IN BRIEF

Press Club lunch

VICTORIA Police Commissioner Simon Overland will address the Rural Press Club of Victoria at a lunch at Skilled Stadium in Geelong on Thursday, January 21. For bookings, phone (03) 9696 5899.

AWB revises pool

GRAIN marketer AWB has revised its 2009-10 estimated pool returns. Benchmark APW grade wheat is now estimated at $263 a tonne in the Eastern Pool and

$257 a tonne in the Western Pool.

Wind farm protest

ABOUT 60 people gathered in Skipton at the weekend to protest about wind farms in central and western Victoria. Organiser Cassie Franzose said protesters were concerned about plans for up to 500 turbines at several locations in the Pyrenees Shire.

Bushfire experts

A TEAM of seven international forest-fire experts arrived in Victoria this week to work with the Department of Sustainability and Environment. DSE Chief Officer Ewan Waller said the International Forest Fire Experts Program would bring experienced firefighters from the US and Canada to Victoria to boost the specialist firefighting expertise before a major bushfire.

Coal contract

RAIL operator Asciano Group has signed a 10-year coal haulage contract with a Queensland joint venture between Aquila Resources Ltd and Brazilianiron ore giant Vale. Isaac Plains Coal Management Pty Ltd will haul up to 1.1 million tonnes a year from the Isaac Plains mine in the Goonyella system to Dalrymple Bay coal terminal near Mackay.

Parliament speech

THE Weekly Times incorrectly quoted Minister for Victorian Industry and Trade Martin Pakula as the source of a Parliamentary speech. It was, in fact, read by Energy and Resources Minister Peter Batchelor.

urn:contentItem:5V9F-RST1-JD3N-50X5-00000-00Firefighting choppers 'all clear'2019-01-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 3Firefighting choppers 'all clear'Mark Schliebs, Robyn Ironside

A fleet of specially built firefighting helicopters has been cleared to resume flying after being grounded when one crashed into a dam, forcing its crew to swim to safety.

The Sikorsky S-64E was being used to fight a fire in Gippsland, Victoria, when it crashed at 7pm on Monday.

Air safety investigators are looking into whether thick smoke or wind were factors in the crash, which led to similar aircraft being grounded on Monday night.

By yesterday afternoon, the remaining five Aircranes in Australia - one in Victoria, two in NSW and one each in South Australia and Western Australia - were cleared to resume flying ahead of total fire bans in Victoria's Mallee, Wimmera and South West districts today.

Captain Keith Gill, co-pilot Mike Davey and engineer Bill Gray were spotted swimming to shore by pilots in another aircraft.

Both pilots have helped to fight fires in Australia in the past, and were being interviewed by air safety officials yesterday.

Darrin McKenzie, the deputy chief fire officer at Forest Fire Management Victoria, said the helicopter, nicknamed "Christine", was hovering above the dam when it lost altitude.

"During a refilling operation at a dam at Mount Gregory, the aircraft crash-landed into the dam about 7pm," Mr McKenzie said.

"Fortunately, the three crew â€¦ were able to get out of the aircraft safely and swim to the shore of the dam where they received medical treatment." The three, all from North America, were taken to hospital but were released yesterday morning. "They're very shaken, they've got bruises after the impact," Mr McKenzie said.

"But thankfully they're all fine and heading back to Melbourne." He said the area was heavily forested and surrounded by hills, and pilots generally were concerned about smoke and downward winds when flying in such areas. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau is investigating the cause of the crash.

Valued at $30 million, the Aircranes have a 9000-litre water carrying capacity, making them a valuable resource for firefighting operations.

Kestrel Aviation, which operates the Aircranes in partnership with US company Erickson, was providing assistance to the ATSB as it investigated the crash.

Kestrel managing director Ray Cronin said although the cause of the crash remained under investigation, he was confident the Aircrane involved was "100 per cent serviceable prior to impact". However, it was unlikely it would be returned to service.

"There's a large amount of damage to the Aircrane and (it) having been underwater won't help the reinstatement of the Aircrane back into a working unit," Captain Cronin said. "We are just grateful the crew is safe, and grateful to the firefighters on the bank who -assisted them." Mr McKenzie said the crew's training had prepared them for such an emergency. "They're very versed in what they do (and) they travel all over the world," he said.

"These aircraft are based in North America, they spend their winter - our summer season - down here. They're very experienced crews.

"Fortunately they were quite close to the water (so) they haven't fallen a great deal of distance before the impact."The return of the Aircranes to service comes as the Bureau of Meteorology forecasts temperatures in the mid-to-high 30s for much of Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5HT0-91H1-DYG0-92RC-00000-00VIC:Recovery begins as Vic bushfire burns2016-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Recovery begins as Vic bushfire burnsMELBOURNE Jan 7

  Great Ocean Road businesses directly affected by the Christmas Day bushfires may be eligible for disaster relief.
   Concessional loans of up to $200,000 are available for primary producers and small businesses directly impacted in natural disasters, subject to eligibility assessments.


   The 2500-hectare Wye River Jamieson Track bushfire destroyed 116 homes in Wye River and Separation Creek and closed the Great Ocean Road for more than 10 days at the height of the holiday season.
   Loans of up to $100,000 are available for primary producers and small businesses indirectly affected, as well as grants to assist with clean-up costs.
   The Great Ocean Road re-opened fully on Wednesday, offering business owners and tourism operators some relief.
   More than 300 firefighters, including 23 dense forest fire specialists from New Zealand, are battling the fire, which is still burning out of control in thick bush.
   Weak winds and cool temperatures have helped firefighters strengthen containment lines around the 2500-hectare Wye River fire, which is burning in dense and mountainous forest.
   Incident controller Gregg Paterson says while some rain is falling, it is only enough to "annoy" firefighters who hope to contain the fire by January 30.
   "This is a very difficult fire," he told AAP on Wednesday.
   "The plan is to have the fire contained by the 30th of January, but if it were earlier, that would be awesome."

urn:contentItem:5RW4-TDP1-JD34-V1W0-00000-00Inspiring young women awarded International Women's Day scholarships2018-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Inspiring young women awarded International Women's Day scholarships

Five young women from across the Bega Valley have been awarded International Women's Day scholarships from the Bega Valley Shire Council.

The scholarships were awarded to support their work with the community and to enable them to achieve their goals and aspirations.

Brianna Larkham and Gab Green from Merimbula, Indigo Walker and Leesa Chen from Bega and Eliza Bell from Wolumla were awarded the $500 scholarships acknowledging their contributions to the community and their future plans.

Founder of Topsy-turvy Intimates, Indigo Walker, has been designing and manufacturing underwear for women that celebrates a range of body shapes and the diversity of women within the community.

Ms Walker said that although making underwear may appear as though she is "not doing anything meaningful for the world", she hopes to empower women through her work, particularly those women who do not fit traditional notions of female attractiveness.

"I was seeing women who did not feel attractive and women that weren't being represented and I wanted to bring them to the forefront."

With the scholarship money, Ms Walker hopes to run a half-day underwear making workshop so other women can also learn how to be creative with their underwear.

"The scholarships means that I have a certain aspect of financial security but also the ability to expand and try different designs."

Boilermaker and forest fire fighter Brianna Larkham was inspired to apply for the scholarship to highlight gender equality.

"I wanted to apply so that I could inspire other local young people to pursue whatever career they want, they don't have to stick to gender norms. There are opportunities out there and no need to be stereotyped, you just have to apply and commit yourself," she said.

The 23-year-old of Pambula began her boiler making trade aged-21. She discontinued her studies in Architecture to "try some thing more hands on", she said.

"I really like it! I have helped build massive dehydrators as well as structural fabrications, like beams for houses and construction sites."

"There is a lot of sexism in the area although I think there are a lot of employers and a lot of people out there that are willing to employ women and give them a go," Ms Larkham said.

After completing her apprenticeship she now has her sights set on becoming a Paramedic, using the scholarship to fund her travel expenses for practical work in Queensland as well as textbooks.

urn:contentItem:5R0X-B0H1-JD3N-524C-00000-00On the backburner2017-11-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1On the backburnerBrittany Shanahan

A LACK of planned burns are putting people's lives at risk in the looming bushfire season, Nillumbik Mayor Peter Clarke warns.

In a sternly worded letter to Emergency Services Minister James Merlino, seen by the Leader, Cr Clarke said he was worried that some planned burns - designed to reduce the shire's fire risk - had been postponed for 12 months.

The burns are now scheduled for autumn next year. But that is small comfort to firefighters facing what is predicted to be a scorching summer.

Cr Clarke said local CFA brigades had told him they were frustrated at the lack of burns completed by the Department of Environment Land Water and Planning (DELWP) and he demanded Mr Merlino provide "adequate" resources for the work.

"I cannot accept that highly populated, at-risk areas such as Eltham and North Warrandyte would not be considered a high priority," Cr Clarke said.

Following the Black Saturday bushfires, which tore through parts of the shire, the 2009 Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission recommended the state implement a long-term program of planned burns, based on an annual rolling target of five per cent minimum of public land.

Doreen CFA captain Chris Maries said there was always room for more planned burns but pointed out it was difficult to get the right conditions heading into summer.

"We can go from too wet to too dangerous in weeks," Capt Maries said. Since 2016, one planned burn was completed in at Boomers Reserve northeast of Panton Hill.

Three other planned burns, Laughing Waters and Overbank Rd in Eltham plus Flora Cres in St Andrews, were scheduled for 2016/17 but postponed and carried into the 2017-18 Fire Operations Plan.

Metro district manager Dan White from Forest Fire Management Vic, a branch of DELWP, said the burns were postponed twice due to fuel moisture and weather conditions.

DELWP did not respond to questions about manpower shortages.The rescheduled burns are now expected to be carried out in autumn 2018.In a statement to Leader, Mr Merlino said: "The Nillumbik community can rest assured that we are prepared for this coming fire season, including a record $29.4 million in Victoria's biggest ever firefighting aircraft fleet."

urn:contentItem:5R0H-4JG1-JD34-V2D4-00000-00Fire publication established in Warracknabeal loses funding2017-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Fire publication established in Warracknabeal loses fundingCarly Werner

WIMMERA volunteers are crushed a statewide fire publication established in Warracknabeal has lost funding.

The Country Fire Authority has withdrawn its annual grant for the Fire Wise magazine, which Captain Norm Tosh formed in the Wimmera town in 1947.

Fire Wise - formerly The Fireman - is Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria's official monthly publication.

The group's Horsham-based state councillor, Maurice Dumesny, said the authority provided thousands of dollars each year - which equated to about $1 for each volunteer statewide - for the publication.

He said Fire Wise was critical for supplying information to volunteers across the state.

"It has been and still is today a great asset to the group," he said.

"It is a way of informing volunteers of brigade news and events, championship results, members service awards, the passing of authority members, and reports on brigade functions raising money for equipment.

"Fire Wise has published stories from Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria, Emergency Management Victoria, the CFA, and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

"My opinion has nothing to do with money but more about trying to stop Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria from having a voice."

In a statement on the Fire Wise website, editor Gordon King said the authority had supported the publication for about 50 years.

He said the funding kept publication costs to a minimum, and helped ensure a free copy of the magazine was available for every brigade captain and group officer each month.

Mr King said while the news was bitterly disappointing, readers should not despair.

"I am determined to make Fire Wise even stronger, more financially secure and even more widely distributed," he said.

"Like the generations who managed The Fireman before me, I am more convinced than ever that it is vitally important for there to be a thriving and respected opportunity for the voice of authority volunteers to be shared, and for the unconstrained conversations about volunteer issues, ideas and opinions to be on the table.

"I know we have many supporters who understand the value and need for a publication such as Fire Wise and I will be working with these people to ensure our ongoing success."

Mr King said the first step was making Fire Wise free online at www.fire-wise.com.au to increase the publication's reach.
